Is it just me, or are people horribly misinterpreting the atmosphere and mood surrounding Kai'Sa?

Just considering her backstory, her home, family, and everyone she's ever known was killed by the void when she was a child (must have been traumatic), she grew up in a dark underground world where the only light came from things or structures created by things that wanted to obliterate/eat her (must have been traumatic), and to survive, she wears the half-alive zombie-corpse of one of the things that wanted to eat her. And then when she finally gets back to the surface where she came from, her people treat her like a monster, like the monsters she's been running from and fighting all her life.

And everyone has these chibi and bright and shiny anime representations of her as if she's some sort of happy-go-lucky magic girl or something. As if her life hasn't been hell or like she's not on the brink of going insane (which I dunno if she is or isn't, the stories don't say, but I can't imagine that kind of solitude in those conditions can be healthy).

The closest thing to what the mood might actually be is the Sinister Kai'Sa, but even that one is frustrating because according to the story, she's not evil, nor does she take pleasure in the hunt.

I am the frustrated! {{sticker:sg-shisa}}

Maybe share some blame with the designer who makes her look like a high-fashion super model. Obviously, the inspiration for all these fan arts are based on the splash art-- which is a beautiful, buxom, badass space agent-type.

From the broken back poses to the gravity defying boobs, it seems as if the only women that are capable of being champions are the models. Only exceptions being children like Annie and Zoe and the Amazonian Illaoi. It's depressing that a character like Taliyah is groundbreaking because her nose structure is different. I remember reading a bit that explained that the facial structure of every female league champ before Taliyah was basically the same. That frustrates me a lot. I don't even think the hollywood-beautiful is all that attractive. The way they have only one template for them is so disappointing and disingenuous.

Indeed, Kalista gets the award for being the only halfway-scary humanoid female in the game.

There are some less-swimsuit-model-proportioned champions, and a couple somewhat older champions among them:

{{champion:420}} {{champion:127}} {{champion:163}} {{champion:102}} 

The rest of the female humanoids are all yordles, children, or hawt chix (as far as I can remember off the top of my head).  And it took YEARS before those entered the game (and they're all cool and unique in their own ways).

Riven almost made the list by being sort of androgynous, but the bunny skin thing sort of threw that off a bit.

Not Sexy is something they finally learned how to do after three seasons or so, starting with Shyvana.

Sexy monsters:

{{champion:69}} {{champion:60}} {{champion:143}} {{champion:145}} 

Even Human Form Elise has, like, a sexy BDSM spider lady costume, even though spiders are naturally scary.  Zyra?  Not all that changed by the transformation.  Cass is still pretty hawt considering she got a Curse Of Unsexy while temptressing around and stealing magic stuff from the wrong dude.

Kai'Sa's lore/visuals mismatch is an unsurprising slide into the old, comics-inspired "always err on the side of sexy" style of thinking.  She does have a cool look, but her look is more in line with, say, a bounty hunter who intentionally innovated the void to use it as a weapon against them or something. She does not look like some monstrosity who fought her way home from hell only to be rejected by family.

Some really creative, visually compelling, scary things COULD be done with transformations like these, but hawt anime lazors are the default fallback.
Should we make the counter argument about all the male characters in the game? No? Because no one cares.

Yeah, it really doesn't look all that horrible and scary.  Cassiopeia is also supposed to be hideous, but is still mostly hawt.

The lore is written more in line with (Star Craft) Kerrigan's visuals, but the execution here is "hawt body suit void chick, 9.5/10 would bang".  Kind of thematically iffy here IMO.

Gut reaction isn't "omg scary hideous, would instinctively shun".  It's "kewl edgy anime hawtness, want angry purple waifu nao plzkthx".  Lore claims that we're supposed to experience the former.

Well what sells will sell but in terms of the actual lore, I don't mind. Everybody goes through horrible things and we shouldn't ever keep it that way. Finding beauty in even the worst of situations is an amazing thing to do. It honestly helped me get through a lot of the stuff I have been through. I choose to find inspiration through these "symbols" not degrade them.

Besides art is the seeking of the beautiful. If you had amazing skills, would you prefer to spend time on something you adore to make it ugly? You wouldn't make your car look like crap especially if it was a Corvette, etc.

I have to totally agree, look at the other beings that came into contact with the void like her own father. There isn't anything lore related as to why her body stays youthful or so "human" like in the void thanks to the symbiote.

Maybe not in League lore, but there are plenty of examples in nature and other fantasy universes of beauty being used to draw in prey. I could see the symbiote maintaining or enhancing her appearance over time (she's had it on since she was a girl, so the organism affecting her physically in such a way makes sense to me) as another way to attract prey. Now granted, the void monsters she hunts probably don't give a shit, but I'm sure the symbiote wouldn't mind some human sized snacks.

Not interested in this character outside of league lore since that's where she exists. Maybe if that's what the writers, Riot universe expanders intended and it definitely should be explicit in their lore if that's the case.

I think primarily 2 things play into this.

1:The art and story don't play it off as if she's traumatized, broken, or hell bent. She's portrayed as righteous in many ways, and far from vengeful or even spiteful towards the void. I feel like the story tellers could've given a little more anger in her character, more sorrow from her past(or current standings with civilization), or both, and given her A LOT more emotional/psychological depth. Rather than someone who essentially embraced the void and now is fighting it for the greater good.

2:Communities often like to take characters out of their natural scene. If something appears bright and cheery, a community will make depictions of twisted horror and nightmares. If something looks terrifying or grotesque, people will make it happy and chibi. This can partly be explained by the simple want of having a character depicted in all scenarios, kinda like the emotion panels where it'll have a character when they're sad, happy, mad, etc. If a character is already happy and excited, they'll need to create an image where they are sad or angry, etc., etc.

Anyway, that's just my 2 cents on the topic.
